segments.text: I am Gerald Parker and I have been asked to reflect upon my background and my relation in the life of Dr. U.E.
Marnie.
I am Gerald Parker and I have been asked to reflect upon my background and my relation in the life of Dr. U.E.
Marnie.
Dr. Brown discussion of his life and habits is a hard act to follow.
I was raised in Navarra County, which is located approximately 50 miles southeast of Dallas.
My family consisted of my mother, father, and three sons.
I was the oldest.
Our family made a living by dry land farming and ranching.
I saved my family because we all had to work very hard just to make a living during the Depression.
My mother and father were honest, God-fearing people, and they expected the same from their sons.
About the time I was in the seventh grade, my dad accepted a position managing certain aspects of a farm and ranch owned by Mr. R.L.
Wheelock, who made his money in the oil business.
We lived three miles from the Powell High School, and if we didn't want to walk, we could run.
While in high school, I worked with the field cattle and the horses at the ranch.
At that time, I decided that if at all possible, I wanted to go to A&M, take animal husbandry and become a ranch foreman.
Dr. Ray Dickerson from Dallas was the ranch veterinarian.
When he made calls to the ranch, I always made sure that I could be on hand and assist him.
When I finally made financial arrangements to go to A&M,
Dr. Dickerson suggested I consider going to the veterinary school.
Having much respect for Dr. Dickerson, I took his advice.
My interest to A&M and enrollment in the School of Veterinary Medicine was one of the most exciting periods of my life.
When I finished my sophomore year in the veterinary school and Dr. Ray Dickerson invited me to go to College Station with him and attend a TVMA meeting, I was delighted.
At this meeting, I met Dr. U.E.
Marnie, and he interviewed me for a summer job at his Alamo Dog and Cat Hospital in San Antonio, Texas.
Probably the reason I got the job, I didn't ask him how much he paid, and I suspect that Dr. Dixon told him that I was not afraid of work.
It was a very exciting summer for me because I gained a great deal of experience.
I was paid $12 per week,
and was furnished a bed in the hospital.
And for the use of the bed, I was granted the privilege of answering the phone and doorbell during the night and on holidays.
We had long hours, and we provided services and sold drugs to anyone on a 24-hour, 365-day basis.
Dr. Virgil Fondren was employed by Dr. Marnie at that time.
Dr. Marnie did very little physical work,
but he knew what was going on at all times, and everyone knew that he was the boss.
I had a great deal of respect for his expertise in veterinary medicine and for his management skills.
Dr. Marnie gave me a position with him after graduation.
After finishing the state board examination late one cold, rainy January evening, I boarded the train and arrived in San Antonio, Texas about sunup the next morning.
Dr. Marnie picked me up at the air depot and allowed me to put in a full day's work that day after a sleepless night.
About two weeks later, I learned that I had passed the state board exam and my license was mailed to me.
Since Dr. Brown has covered Dr. Marnie's life and habits, let me share a couple of humorous things we enjoyed about him.
Dr. Marnie was almost bald-headed and he had a small tumor on the top of his head
that was very noticeable.
One morning, Dr. Marty came into the office wearing his usual attire.
While he was in the adjoining room, a client, as I believe this person to be qualified though as a customer, came in.
He said he wanted to talk to the old man.
Since Dr. Fondren had a little age under his belt, I inquired which doctor he wanted to see.
He stated that he wanted to see the old man with a grub in his head.
After dealing with the customer, Doctor Marnie got dressed and left in his car.
About two and a half hours later, he returned with a patch on his head.
He never mentioned a word about having the tumor removed, and it goes without saying it was never mentioned by anyone else.
Another time.
Everyone was occupied and a client wanted a rabies vaccination for their dog.
They were in a hurry and was about to leave.
Dr. Marty, not wanting to lose a dollar vaccination, decided to perform the test himself.
Instead of putting a needle on the syringe from the sterilizer, he picked up a blunt-ended Tomcat catheter.
His vision wasn't too good at that time.
When I got into the exam room to relieve him, he was still trying to push that blunt-ended Tomcat catheter through the skin of that dog.
Needless to say, the Tom Gatt catheter was never placed in with the needles again.
Dr. Marty demanded that everyone, clients, employees, and even his wife show respect for his veterinarians.
He paid good salaries for that day and time, and he expected loyalty and hard work in return.
He insisted that his employed veterinarians become active in organized veterinary medicine.
He had gone through all the chairs himself.
In October of 1943, I left the employment of Dr. Marnie and became employed by the United States Army.
R.A. Culpepper became my replacement.
In closing, let me tell you that Dr. Marnie had a great deal of influence on my life, especially in pursuing an active role in organized veterinary medicine.
I have had over 40 wonderful years of being an associate and partner to R.D.
Brown,
And I hope to get to put up with him many more.
Since Dr. Marnie was responsible for bringing us together, he would be very proud to know that our relationship has lasted this long.
Thank you.
Our relationship has lasted this long.
Thank you.
